skills.name: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication
Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division

explanations.A: I think you have put the numbers next to each other. What does x 3 x 4 give? You could try it out on a few numbers to see.
explanations.C: I think you have added the numbers. What does x 3 x 4 give? You could try it out on a few numbers to see.
explanations.D: Not quite. What does x 3 x 4 give? You could try it out on a few numbers to see.

explanations.A: I think you have put the numbers next to each other. What does x 4 x 5 give? You could try it out on a few numbers to see.
explanations.B: I think you have added the numbers. What does x 4 x 5 give? You could try it out on a few numbers to see.
explanations.D: Not quite. What does x 4 x 5 give? You could try it out on a few numbers to see.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try out both methods and see which one(s) work.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try out both methods and see which one(s) work.
explanations.C: 12 x 7 x 3 = 12 x 21 so Tom is correct. 21 x 6 x 2 = 21 x 12 so Katie is also correct.
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one person is correct. Try out both methods and see which one(s) work.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try out both methods and see which one(s) work.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try out both methods and see which one(s) work.
explanations.C: 28 x 5 x 3 = 28 x 15 so Tom is correct. 14 x 15 x 2 = 14 x 2 x 15 = 28 x 15 so Katie is also correct.
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one person is correct. Try out both methods and see which one(s) work.

explanations.A: Tom is correct as we can reorder the multiplications to get 8 x 3 x 9 x 2 = 24 x 18. Katie is incorrect as we have 80 x 80.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try reordering the multiplications so you can get a 24 and an 18.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try reordering the multiplications so you can get a 24 and an 18.
explanations.D: Not quite. Try reordering the multiplications so you can get a 24 and an 18.

explanations.A: Tom is correct as we have 7 x 4 = 28 and 5 x 3 = 15, so 28 x 15. Katie is incorrect as the order of operations means this would be 20 + 80 + 5
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember we have to use BIDMAS with all our calculations. Use this to see if they would work.
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember we have to use BIDMAS with all our calculations. Use this to see if they would work.
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one person is correct. Remember we have to use BIDMAS with all our calculations. Use this to see if they would work.

explanations.A: Dividing by 10 and then by 4 is the same as splitting an amount into 10 piles, and then each of those piles into 4, leaving 10 x 4 = 40 piles, so we are dividing by 40
explanations.B: I think you have divided the 10 by 4. Think about this as sharing. You are splitting something into 10 piles, and then splitting each of those into 4 piles.
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted 4 from 10. Think about this as sharing. You are splitting something into 10 piles, and then splitting each of those into 4 piles.
explanations.D: I think you have divided the 4 by 10. Think about this as sharing. You are splitting something into 10 piles, and then splitting each of those into 4 piles.

explanations.A: I think you have divided the 5 by 4. Think about this as sharing. You are splitting something into 5 piles, and then splitting each of those into 4 piles.
explanations.B: Dividing by 5 and then by 4 is the same as splitting an amount into 5 piles, and then each of those piles into 4, leaving 5 x 4 = 20 piles, so we are dividing by 20
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted the 4 from 5. Think about this as sharing. You are splitting something into 5 piles, and then splitting each of those into 4 piles.
explanations.D: I think you have divided the 4 by 5. Think about this as sharing. You are splitting something into 5 piles, and then splitting each of those into 4 piles.

explanations.A: Not quite. Think about the methods in terms of sharing, and see if either end up splitting 296 into 8 equal piles.
explanations.B: Katie is correct as dividing 296 by 2, then 2 then 2 will split 296 into 8 equal piles. Tom is incorrect as he would have a tenth of 296 - half of 296 which is not 1/8 of 296 (1/10 - 1/2 = -4/10)
explanations.C: Not quite. Think about the methods in terms of sharing, and see if either end up splitting 296 into 8 equal piles.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think about the methods in terms of sharing, and see if either end up splitting 296 into 8 equal piles.

explanations.A: Not quite. Think about the methods in terms of sharing, and see if either end up splitting 371 into 7 equal piles.
explanations.B: Katie is correct as dividing 350 by 7 and 21 by 7 and adding them is the same as dividing the total 371 by 7. Tom is incorrect as he would have a tenth of 371 - a third of 371 which is not 1/7 of 371 (1/10 - 1/3 = -7/30)
explanations.C: Not quite. Think about the methods in terms of sharing, and see if either end up splitting 371 into 7 equal piles.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think about the methods in terms of sharing, and see if either end up splitting 371 into 7 equal piles.
